creator: jshin@jtan.com
text:
httpd.conf-dist has the following lines: 

    # Italian (it) - Korean (kr) - Norwegian (no) - Norwegian Nynorsk (nn)
    # Portugese (pt) - Luxembourgeois* (ltz)
 
    AddLanguage kr .kr
    AddCharset ISO-2022-KR .iso-kr

'kr' is NOT the language code for Korean BUT the country code for Republic of
Korea(South Korea). 'ko' is the language code for Korean. Moreover, I can bet a
million buck that there's NOT a single web page written in ISO-2022-KR.
ISO-2022-KR WAS (NOT any more) used for Korean internet email in 1990's but was
NEVER used for web publishing. EUC-KR and Windows-949(MS IIS incorrectly refers
to it as ksc5601.1987-0) are two most common MIME charset(Character Encoding)
used for Korean document with UTF-8 catching up recently. Therefore the above
lines should be replaced by

  AddLanguage ko .ko
  AddCharset EUC-KR .euckr

I had reported this  a couple of times before Apache bugzilla was set up but
I've just found that it's still not fixed. It'd be nice if this could be fixed.

creator: trawick@apache.org
text:
I'm going through the bug db to make sure patches are findable.  Please see 
http://httpd.apache.org/dev/patches.html

I found another mistake of the same kind at

http://httpd.apache.org/docs/content-negotiation.html

The document has the following:

Content-Language:
    The languages of the variant, specified as an Internet standard language tag
from RFC 1766 (e.g., en for English, kr for Korean, etc.).

Again, 'kr' is NOT the language code for Korean but the country code for the
Republic of Korea (South Korea). 

Perhaps, this has to be filed as a separate bug (because it belongs to a
different component), but it's so trivial.... Would you please fix these two
bugs? Thanks
